Subject: Re: [neat] Alternating loss functions for evolution

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;

Hello,

Changing the loss function can be very helpful, but it=E2=80=99s ev=
en better if you have multiple loss functions in parallel and let a populat=
ion of solutions =E2=80=9Cgoal switch=E2=80=9D between whichever objective =
they are currently the best. 

That=E2=80=99s the spirit behind Quality Div=
ersity algorithms, including the following ideas/papers, which I recommend =
checking out:

Innovation Engines:
Journal <http://www.evolvingai.org/nguye=
n-yosinski-clune-2016-understanding-innovation>
Summary page <http://www.ev=
olvingai.org/innovationengine>
CMOEA <http://www.evolvingai.org/cmoea>
NSLC=
 <https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3D2001606>
MAP-Elites <https://arxiv.o=
rg/abs/1504.04909>
Our recent POET algorithm <https://eng.uber.com/poet-ope=
n-ended-deep-learning/>
etc


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Loy and Edith Harri=
s Associate Professor in Computer Science
Director, Evolving Artificial Int=
elligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@uwyo=
.edu <mailto:jeffclune@...>
jeffclune.com <http://jeffclune.com/>

Sen=
ior Research Manager (Staff Scientist)
Uber AI Labs <http://uber.ai/>

> On=
 Apr 9, 2019, at 11:50 PM, sean_c4s@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com>=
 wrote:
> 
> Evolutionary algorithms often get stuck as you know very well.=
  I was just thinking that if you were to alternate the loss function used =
from time to time that would help maintain the dynamics.  For example switc=
hing between the L2 and L1 loss function.  The sum of the square of the err=
or terms versus the sum of the absolutes of the error terms.  I haven't tri=
ed it yet, perhaps it will be useful.
> Here is another example of the loca=
lity sensitive hash (LSH) associative memory:
> http://gamespace.eu5.org/as=
sociativememory/index.html <http://gamespace.eu5.org/associativememory/inde=
x.html> 
> Which might be useful for Neural Turing Machines.  One person wa=
s complaining it was not differential compatible but you can change the har=
d binarization in the LSH with a soft version, any type of squashing functi=
on will do etc. 
> Also since I'm doing JavaScript at the moment there is t=
he "Continuous Gray Code" optimization algorithm again...:
> http://gamespa=
ce.eu5.org/monalisa/index.html <http://gamespace.eu5.org/monalisa/index.htm=
l>
> 
> You can save the pages if you want to get at the JavaScript code. 
=
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_B1BE4085-173A-43D8-BF9F-8162300CC44D

 alternate the loss function used from time to time that would help maintai=
n the dynamics.  For example switching between the L2 and L1 loss func=
tion.  The sum of the square of the error terms versus the sum of the =
absolutes of the error terms.  I haven't tried it yet, perhaps it will=
 be useful.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">Here is another ex=
ample of the locality sensitive hash (LSH) associative memory:<br style=3D"=

ine-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">Which might be useful for Neural Turing Mac=
hines.  One person was complaining it was not differential compatible =
but you can change the hard binarization in the LSH with a soft version, an=
y type of squashing function will do etc.<span class=3D"Apple-converted-spa=
ce"> </span><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">Also since I=
